message:
إستفسار يا جماعة عن وسائل الدفع الإلكترونى وإيه أضمنهم و أسهلهم بالنسبة للمستخدم العربى 
يعنى لو عندك ويب سايت بيقدم خدمة بمقابل مادى يا ترى إيه أحسن وسائل الدفع من ناحية السهولة على المستخدم وكمان من ناحية إنه يبقى حاسس بالأمان والثقة 
وكلامى طبعا عن المستخدم العربى

data.message: متهيألي أنسب حاجه حاليا هي الـ Premium SMS بالنسبة للخدمات الاليكترونية اللي سعرها قليل Micro Payments، صحيح بيوصل جيبك في الآخر ربما 30% من اللي دفعه العميل لكن في المقابل تقدر تبيع بها أكتر بكتير لأن الناس مش هتكسل ولا هتخاف تدفع بها، لو بتبيع حاجات مش اليكترونية أحسن حاجه الدفع عند الاستلام
وطبعا في كل الأحوال لازم تدعم كل طرق الدفع في موقعك

tl;dr: Online payments in Egypt is a dead end, if you can avoid it by incorporating your business outside Egypt then you've done your business and your sanity a great service.

---
For on-site credit card processing:
- 2Checkout
- Spreedly
- Payfort
- BlueSnap

For off-site credit card processing:
- Skrill moneybookers
- Wallety
- CashU
- Fastspring

2Checkout has one of the most rigid admission processes I've seen so far, mostly end up in rejection. They also require the merchant to be a registered legal entity.

Spreedly will require the merchant to be a registered legal entity because the only reason they support Egypt is because they support MiGS and the only two banks that offer MiGS are the Al Ahly bank and the Arab African bank.
Both of which are not so keen on giving out merchant accounts specially to a company they don't have a joint contract with, like Spreedly.

Note: Dealing with banks in Egypt to acquire a merchant account is no different than selling your soul to the devil to get a meal you're willing to pay for.

Payfort will require the merchant to be a registered legal entity because 
1) It's too expensive 
2) It has a joint contract with Al Ahly bank 
3) You'll need to sign a contract with them and the bank

Note: Payfort's system is notoriously bad, poorly documented and just shit stupid. But... It works, not so well for recurring billing though (You'll end up implementing a recurring payments system on top of their Gateway).

BlueSnap is like Payfort. Except Payfort is Arab (Duabi based with an Egyptian founder if I'm not mistaken)

Skrill (Formally moneybookers) is just crap. Steer away from it, it follows the traditional model of redirecting a customer to their website. One good point about them is you can  charge non-skrill users.

Wallety is Egyptian, same model as Skrill but require your customers to have an account on Wallety

CashU similar to the previous two, also require your customers to have an account but popular and trusted amongst Arabs

FastSpring is so far the only off-site experience that's somewhat acceptable, but it's invitation only and they're extremely selective.

If I had to recommend something, I'd recommend not accepting payments as an Egyptian business and incorporate outside Egypt. In such case you'll have access to one of the following four which I highly recommend:

- Stripe
- Pin payments in Australia
- Paymill in Europe
- Authorize.net

Since establishing a business outside Egypt for non-residents is notoriously painful for most people, I'd recommend CashU, FastSpring or Spreedly.

Good luck.
Cash or SMS in Egypt, PayPal in gulf, like UAE.
